thread.title: Indian Ocean islands on the look-out for MH370 debris
thread.title_full: Indian Ocean islands on the look-out for MH370 debris

title: Indian Ocean islands on the look-out for MH370 debris
text:
Save 
Malaysia has asked islands in the Indian Ocean near the French-owned Reunion to keep an eye out for more possible debris, after a wing part suspected of being from missing flight MH370 came ashore 
The wing part discovered on Wednesday has been taken to mainland France for tests, but it has since been confirmed that other items found at the weekend were not from the aircraft. 
The BBC’s Karen Allen, who is on Reunion, said one of the pieces had been found on a rocky beach, north of where the suspected plane wing part had been spotted. 
Police and police photographers were called and the object was taken away. 
However, Malaysia’s director general of Civil Aviation Azharuddin Abdul Rahman told Associated Press: “I read all over media [the new debris] was part of a door. But I checked with the Civil Aviation Authority, and people on the ground in Reunion, and it was just a domestic ladder.” 
Meanwhile, the Agence France-Presse news agency said on Sunday that one of its photographers had also seen a mangled piece of metal inscribed with two Chinese characters, attached to a leather-covered handle and measuring 100 sq cm, which was placed into an iron case and carried away. 
Some social media commentators have suggested it might be a kettle. 
A source close to the inquiry told AFP that “no object or debris likely to come from a plane” had been submitted as evidence on Sunday. 
A spokesperson in the town of St Andre said that while people were more vigilant, “they are going to think any metallic object they find on the beach is from flight MH370”.
